instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3208: What is 820-3208? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.R6905: What is R6905? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on older Macbooks, pre-2011 models. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no light no nothing
threads.message:
need help with this board
came in just a little dusty, but no real corrosion or liquid traces

get 0,3V on PP3v42
testing of course with known good DCINboard and LIO Cable.
<RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> was replaced because it looked blown and showed a drop in voltage on pin 1 18.49V to pin 2: 2,49V, but ofcourse it blew again.

am i correct in thinking that that can be caused by a short on pp3v42?
PP3V42 measures no resistance to ground (literally with my fucked up multimeter, 0,01 Ohms)

Are there any usual suspects to this rail that i am overseeing?
Have tried taking off the caps around <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> itself, no change in resistance.
​​​​​​​should i suspect something around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no light no nothing
threads.message: Inject voltage and see what heats up. You likely have a short on 3v42. Check caps near SMC as well. I'd say try everything you can that is not the SMC first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no light no nothing
threads.message: Not really a common suspect besides the SMC itself. Indeed inject voltage on the 3V42 bus. Start low and monitor current. See if SMC is getting hot if not look for other things that may heat up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no light no nothing
threads.message:
OK, have put current through it, started at 1v and cranked to 2v, only thing that gets hot is the ISL (SMC stays cold). So decided to replace the ISL as I have plenty on 3437donors lying around. didn't change anything.
is the next suspect the SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no light no nothing
threads.message: I have replaced the SMC as well in the meantime, there is no change in symptoms. Is it ok to take off the SMC again and look for shorts that way? Or any hints on what to suspect next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no light no nothing
threads.message: IF there is a short something should heat up when you inject 3V. Sure you can remove the SMC and look for shorts again, but should not be needed. Is the short still there?
